captions.text: [radio static]

(President James E. Faust)
How are you possibly

going to select what voices
you will listen to and believe?

You will not be able to travel
through life on borrowed light.

The voice you must learn to
heed is the voice of the Spirit.

The Spirit's voice is
ever-present but it is calm.

The adversary tries
to smother His voice

with a multitude of loud,
persistent, appealing voices.

Murmuring voices that conjure
up perceived injustices,

pointing voices of that abhor
challenge and work,

seductive voices offering
sensual enticements,

flattering voices that
puff us up with pride,

commercial voices that
tempt us to spend money

for that which is
of no worth

and our labor for that
which cannot satisfy.

In your generation,
you will be barraged

by multitudes of voices
telling you how to live,

how to gratify your passions,
how to have it all.

There will be all sorts
of software,

satellite receivers and
communication networks

that will suffocate you
with information.

You will be bombarded
with evil and wickedness
like no other generation.

As I contemplate this prospect,
I'm reminded of
T.S. Elliot's words:

"Where is the wisdom
we have lost in knowledge?

Where is the knowledge
we have lost in information?"

I have suggested
a simple solution

for selecting the channel which
you will attune yourselves to.

Listen to and follow
the voice of the Spirit.
This is an ancient solution,

even eternal, and
may not be popular

in a society whose always
looking for something new.

This solution requires
patience in a world

that demands
instant gratification.

This solution is quiet,
peaceful and subtle.

This solution requires you
to walk by faith

in a world governed
by sight.

Learn to ponder the things
of the Spirit

and respond
to its promptings.

Filter out the static generated
by Satan.

As you become attune
to the Spirit,

"thine ears shall hear
a word behind thee

saying this is the way,
walk ye in it."

Hearkening to the voice
of the living God

will give you peace in
this world and eternal life
in the world to come.

These are the greatest
of all the gifts of God.

Please talk to Heavenly Father. He will help you - strengthen you and give

many years ago I learned the greatest lesson of my life - if you TRUST  - 
if you LISTEN - if you PRAY - it always improves as long as you believe in 
Jesus Christ.﻿

comments.author: C E Mason

comments.text:
Our hearts may be impure and our minds may be mistaken, but God is always 
right, and we are never wrong to the extent that we stand with Him.  Which 
is one reason why we should persistently strive to follow His gentle 
guidance of the Holy Spirit as best as we can perceive it and distinguish 
that guidance from alternative spiritual sources.  The gift of the Holy 
Spirit, through which we are enable to receive His constant companionship, 
is the greatest heavenly gift that we may enjoy during this mortal sojourn, 
and His guidance helps lead us to eternal life through Jesus Christ the 
Savior, which is the greatest heavenly gift of all.  May we be grateful for 
this gift and strive to make the most of it.﻿
comments.author: David Edward Garber

comments.text:
"For you outstanding young men and women there is a scriptural text found 
in the Doctrine and Covenants:  'Give ear to the voice of the living God' 
(D&C 50:1).  The voice of the Spirit is universally available to all.  The 
Lord said, 'The Spirit enlighteneth every man [and every woman] . . . that 
hearkeneth to the voice of the Spirit' (D&C 84:46).  He further says that 
'everyone that hearkeneth to the voice of the Spirit cometh unto God, even 
the Father' (D&C 84:47).  Some people are seeking to find the abundant 
life.  Paul made it clear that it is 'the Spirit [that] giveth life' (2 
Corinthians 3:6).  Indeed, the Savior said, 'The words that I speak unto 
you, they are spirit, and they are life' (John 6:63)." -- James E. Faust

http://speeches.byu.edu/?act=viewitem&id=771
comments.author: David Edward Garber

comments.text:
This truth, that "there is no v. in living a mytholog. lifest.," is 
demonstrated unequivocally by Elijah in 1 Kings 18. However, there have 
indeed been many during the temporal history of this earth who have "put 
[their] trust in that Spirit which leadeth to do good—yea, to do justly, to 
walk humbly, to judge righteously" (Doc. & Covenants 11:12). The "natural 
man [receives] not the things of the Spirit of God" (1 Cor. 2:14), but they 
can be received "by the prayer of faith" (D.&C. 42:14)!

comments.text:
Studying the scriptures helps me to feel calm, understand what to do, and 
have peace inside myself. I find it easier to be nice to other people, more 
patient, and if I study the scriptures AND pray fervently, life is so much 
better. I have done this for the past few months, intently almost every 
day. Tonight I realized that my life has become truly rich. I have 
discovered how to really feel the love of God, most of the time. I am 
understanding things that have puzzled me for years. Injoy!

comments.text:
@blackday12341 : The voice of the Spirit is calm, peaceful, and comforting, 
bringing gladness and joy to your heart and mind. It may be a sudden, 
unbidden flow of pure intelligence into your mind--otherwise known as a 
prompting or as inspiration. The voice of the Spirit is gentle. You must 
study your question out in your mind, make a determination, and then ask 
God if it be right. The Spirit will grant you an assurance if it is right. 
You will feel and know it is so without a doubt.
comments.author: rippinsteo

comments.text:
@TheoneHeroman : I love the Bible. I rejoice in the Savior's words in the 
book of John chapter 14 verses 16 and 26. The Holy Ghost is another 
comforter--the voice of the Spirit--whom the Savior promised would 
'...teach you all things, and bring all things to your remembrance, 
whatsoever I have said unto you.'
comments.author: rippinsteo
